Dave,
  I too have struggled with the equil solver, so your mention of a 
=
new solver was very interesting. However, when I tried to run 
Cantrera 1.5=
.5 in Matlab 7.0.1 (WinXP) I was given the following 
error:

>> equilibrat=
e(gas, 'TP',1)
??? Error using =3D=3D> ThermoPhase.equilibrate
Too many inp=
ut arguments.

When I view the code for equilibrate it seems that more than=
 two 
input arguments is not allowed:

function a =3D equilibrate(a, xy)
% =
EQUILIBRATE  Set the phase to a state of chemical equilibrium.
%
%   The se=
cond argument must be one of the strings 'TP', 'TV',
%   'HP', 'SP', 'SV', =
'UV', 'PT', 'VT', 'PH', 'PS', 'VS', or 'VU',
%   and specifies the two ther=
modynamic properties held fixed at
%   the values in the initial state. Not=
e that if U, H, V, or S is
%   specified, it is the specific value (per uni=
t mass), not the
%   molar value, that is held fixed.
%
if nargin ~=3D 2
  =
error('two arguments required')
end
...

So what am I doing wrong? I would =
very much like to try your new 
solver as speed is not a problem for me at =
this point.

- Carl

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwi=
n@c...> wrote:
>  From what you describe, it is hard to know where the prob=
lem is.  
Maybe 
> the equilibrium solver is having trouble converging.  Yo=
u can tell 
it 
> to use the new solver by giving a third non-zero paramete=
r to 
> equilibrate, e.g.:
> 
> equilibrate(gas, 'TP', 1)
> 
> If the third=
 paramter is missing or zero, the old solver will be 
used, 
> which is fas=
ter but less stable than the new one.  Equilibrium 
problem 
> usually aris=
e from specifying very hard initial conditions, like an 
> exactly stoichio=
metric fuel/air mixture at 300 K. Nevertheless, the 
new 
> solver should h=
andle these cases.
> 
> Other than that, you will need to do some debugging=
 to isolate the 
> problem.  Since the transport demo works, you can start =
with it and 
> modify it one line at a time until it looks like your m-file=
 that 
> fails. In that way, you should be able to track down exactly what =

> change causes failure.  If it is not due to an initial condition 
and 
>=
 seems to be something in Cantera, then see how small an m-file you 
can 
>=
 create that still fails by removing extraneous lines.  For example, 
> doe=
s it fail if you only do equillibrium? Or do you need to compute 
> transpo=
rt propertiess for it to fail?
> 
> Once you have isolated the problem, sen=
d the short m-file to me, 
and I 
> can see if it fails for me too, and see=
 what the problem is.
> 
> 
> 
>

ang wrote:

result,

port properties,

 such as 'segmentation 
error'.

I just try run different 
times.

it is related to memory. 
Any help

problem.
